comments:
ENVS 200 exposes students to the principles that underlie our understanding of
how the Earth works. The goal of this class is to obtain a scientific understanding of the
entire Earth system by describing its component parts (lithosphere, hydrosphere,
atmosphere, biosphere) and their interactions, and describe how they have evolved, how
they function, and how they are expected to respond to human activity. Students work to
develop the capability to predict those changes that will occur in the next decade, both
naturally and in response to human activity. Natural and human-generated energy is used
as a unifying principle. Knowledge gained through this course helps students make
informed decisions in all spheres of human activity: science, policy, economics, etc.
Many students commented that homework assignments involved a lot of busy
work and were very tedious. The class used clickers to gauge students’ understanding.
Many found the grading on homework and exams “nitpicky.”
Students describe Professor Plante as “helpful” and “likeable.” They felt that
Professor Plante expressed enthusiasm for the subject and gave interesting lectures.
Environmental studies majors seemed to find this course more interesting than nonmajors.
The course focuses on parts of the environment that won’t necessarily pique
non-majors’ interest, such as soil.
